title: Key Events in Nuclear History
description: A detailed timeline of major scientific, technological, and policy milestones in the history of nuclear energy and science.

events.title: Discovery of Radioactivity
events.description: Henri Becquerel discovers radioactivity while studying phosphorescence in uranium salts, laying the foundation for nuclear science.

events.title: Radium and Polonium Discovered
events.description: Marie and Pierre Curie isolate radium and polonium, advancing the understanding of radioactive materials.

events.title: Structure of the Atom
events.description: Ernest Rutherford proposes the nuclear model of the atom, identifying the dense, positively charged nucleus.

events.title: Discovery of the Neutron
events.description: James Chadwick discovers the neutron, a key component of atomic nuclei, enabling further advancements in nuclear research.

events.title: Nuclear Fission Identified
events.description: Lise Meitner, Otto Hahn, and Fritz Strassmann discover the process of nuclear fission, demonstrating the splitting of atomic nuclei.

events.title: First Controlled Chain Reaction
events.description: Enrico Fermi and his team achieve the first controlled nuclear chain reaction at the University of Chicago.

events.title: Atomic Bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki
events.description: The United States drops atomic bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki, demonstrating the devastating power of nuclear weapons.

events.title: Manhattan Project Completed
events.description: The Manhattan Project develops the first nuclear weapons, marking the beginning of the nuclear age.

events.title: First Nuclear Power Generated
events.description: The Experimental Breeder Reactor I (EBR-I) in Idaho produces electricity using nuclear energy for the first time.

events.title: Launch of the USS Nautilus
events.description: The USS Nautilus becomes the first nuclear-powered submarine, demonstrating the potential of nuclear energy for propulsion in January 1954.

events.title: First Nuclear Power Plant
events.description: The Obninsk Nuclear Power Plant became the first to generate electricity in June 1954.

events.title: Establishment of the IAEA
events.description: The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) is founded to promote peaceful uses of nuclear energy and ensure nonproliferation.

events.title: Windscale Reactor Fire
events.description: The first major nuclear reactor accident occurs in the UK, highlighting the importance of reactor safety.

events.title: Three Mile Island Accident
events.description: A partial meltdown occurs at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant in Pennsylvania, USA, raising concerns about nuclear safety.

events.title: Chernobyl Disaster
events.description: The catastrophic explosion of Reactor 4 at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant in Ukraine causes widespread radioactive contamination.

events.title: CTBT Opened for Signature
events.description: The Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty (CTBT) is introduced to prohibit nuclear explosions globally.

events.title: Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Disaster
events.description: A tsunami triggered by an earthquake causes a meltdown at the Fukushima Daiichi plant in Japan, reigniting global nuclear safety concerns.

events.title: Iran Nuclear Deal
events.description: The Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) is signed, limiting Iran's nuclear activities in exchange for sanctions relief.

events.title: ICAN Wins Nobel Peace Prize
events.description: The International Campaign to Abolish Nuclear Weapons (ICAN) is recognized for efforts to achieve the Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons.

events.title: SMR Development
events.description: Small Modular Reactors (SMRs) gained significant traction as a safer alternative.

events.title: Nuclear Fusion Milestone
events.description: The National Ignition Facility achieves a major breakthrough in inertial confinement fusion, advancing the quest for fusion energy.

events.title: SMRs Begin Deployment
events.description: Small Modular Reactors (SMRs) are commercially deployed, offering a flexible and scalable approach to nuclear power generation.
